learning_outcomes.description: Describe in detail the anatomy and histology of structures within and around the oral cavity, including their clinical appearance using appropriate terms.
Demonstrate an understanding of the basic biologic sciences relevant to dentistry, including embryology at a fundamental level as well as normal tooth development and eruption.
Understand the role of both microbes and saliva in the oral environment, in both health and common dental diseases and conditions.
Demonstrate an understanding of the basic physical and chemical sciences relevant to dentistry, including physical forces and acid-base and solubility equilibria.
Use contemporary information technologies to critically identify and evaluate scientific evidence while contributing effectively to collaborative teamwork.

assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, you will find literature relevant to a chosen dental science myth, and then systematically analyse this literature to evaluate the strength of the claims made and develop your own written argument that supports or debunks the myth.

The purpose of this assessment task is three-fold:

  • To demonstrate your ability to produce an accurate written report in the form of a 750‑word commentary that explains the science underpinning a popular science myth relevant to dentistry.
  • To assess your ability to evaluate arguments and integrate evidence from selected peer-reviewed literature, as well as any other sources of evidence you choose to support your own argument.
  • To provide feedback on your skills in formal academic writing, including overall structure, logical progression, flow, paragraph structures, and use of an appropriate citation style.

The written report should be pitched to individuals with high health and science literacy, and includes professional peers in Dentistry.

Criteria and marking information will be available on the UQ.Learn site for this course.

You should choose a common topic within a wider team of 5 - 6 students. Each of you will critically examine the same 'popular science' myth. However, you must complete this assessment task individually.

assessments.task_description:
For this assessment, you will investigate and analyse scientific literature related to a selected dental science myth.

Working in a team of 5-6 students, you will create an accurate and engaging infographic that either supports or debunks your chosen myth for the group work.

You will present your infographic in person and explain the scientific reasoning behind your conclusions using language that is accessible for individuals with low health and science literacy.

The purpose of this assessment task is three-fold:

  • To evaluate your ability to work effectively as part of a team.
  • To demonstrate your capacity to communicate scientific concepts accurately and engagingly to a lay audience by creating an oral health infographic that explains the science behind a common dental-related myth that you may encounter in your future clinical practice, and presenting to an audience in person.
  • To assess your ability to critically evaluate arguments and integrate evidence from selected peer‑reviewed literature, along with any other credible sources you choose, to support your own position on the myth.

All team members must present in the allocated in-person session.

You will have the opportunity to select your team members in one of the small group learning sessions. The teams will comprise 4 or 5 individuals from your tutorial group. All team members will receive the same mark for the content of the infographic and the presentation.

You will be required to rate the contribution of each team member against specific teamwork skills criteria and provide a short professional defence of your ratings. This will result in a peer assessment factor being applied to the overall mark for each student.

Criteria and marking information will be available on the UQ.Learn site for this course.
